channel.title: Home on Samuel Rowland's Sports Blog
channel.description: Recent content in Home on Samuel Rowland's Sports Blog

item.title: Is Nebraska's Defensive Play Improving in the Big Ten?
item.description: Nebraska football and its fan base hasn’t had much to cheer about as of late. The last three seasons of Scott Frost’s tenure has only resulted in around three to four wins each season. While last years win record was an improvement to 4 wins overall, it doesn’t place Nebraska anywhere near the conversation when it comes to championships. However, people watching at home this season saw the defense improve, which gives the fans reason for hope.

item.title: Samuel's Sports Analysis Blog
item.description: Hi! I’m Samuel Rowland. I am a student at UNL in the major of Sports Media and Communications. I grew up in Gretna, Nebraska, and I am a passionate Nebraska fan. Some other sports teams that I like are the Golden State Warriors and the St. Louis Cardinals. Addiitonally, I am also an Eagle Scout.

item.title: Another Note on A blogdown Tutorial
item.description: I just discovered an awesome tutorial on blogdown written by Alison. I have to admit this is the best blogdown tutorial I have seen so far.

item.title: A Quick Note on Two Beautiful Websites
item.description: To me, the two most impressive websites based on blogdown are: Rob J Hyndman’s personal website. Live Free or Dichotomize by Lucy and Nick et al. I’m sure there will be more.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This sample post is mainly for blogdown users. If you do not use blogdown, you can skip the first section. 1. Markdown or R Markdown This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc.
